Responding to the base rate analysis of @cpschneider at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/5855362. Thank you, Christian Schneider.

Taking months with relevant incidents as the unit of analysis, according to ACLED data, the rate of occurrence of riots in Mozambique in any given month is 39% in the past two decade. However, in the past decade (2007-2016) this rate was elevated with 71 out of 120 months or approximately 60%. Since the elections in 2009 months in which occurred were clearly more common compared to the previous years on record (70%). With the median number of months per year in which riots occurred being 8 between 2009 and 2016, in only one year since 2009, there were riots in less than half of all months (the current count is 4 according to ACLED data). Overall, 70% seems be a reasonably conservative base rate.

Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Recent Riot/Protest events in Mozambique:
Riots/Protests
10 May 2017 (Frelimo party youths broke up an MDM meeting, causing clashes between the 2 parties. )
12 July 2017 (Technical and administrative staff of Eduardo Mondlane University (UEM) begin a labour strike over non payment of bonuses. A violent protest over the issue occurred the following day. )
13 July 2017 (Staff of Eduardo Mondlane University violently protest over non-payment of bonuses. Riot force police used rubber bullets and tear gas grenades to disperse the demonstrators. No reported injuries. )
13 July 2017 (A stray bullet shot by police killed a worker during a protest in Moatize, causing the other workers to riot, vandalizing a generator and other company equipment. )
26 July 2017 (Workers at Maragra Sugar Mill, north of Maputo, began a strike to demand better wages.)
9 Aug 2017 (Workers at Maragra Sugar Mill rioted and destroyed property. The riot police were called in and clashed with the protesters. 2 civilians and 2 police officers were injured. )
4 Sept 2017 (Loggers in Manica protested the Manica Forest Industry company.

There have been protests in four of the past nine months. I don't see any pattern in the reasons for the protests; they appear to be about separate issues. So I'm taking 4/9 as an approximate base rate.
ACLED reports riots/protests in May/July/August/September 2017. Base rate for riot/protest events in Mozambique seems high.

Considering the reported type of causes, by ACLED, for recent riots and protests in Mozambique, it seems they are likely to happen throughout Mozambique in October. The reported causes were for disputes over wages for loggers, sugar cane mill workers, and staff bonuses at a university, and, the far more serious reports of police shootings that led to deaths and riots. For those caused by the police not to occur, it would require a major concerted police training program with emphasis on both crowd control and the appropriate use of force. Even if immediately implemented and with strong departmental and political backing plus strong civil and NGO watch groups, this would require months to accomplish. The labor wage issue could easily go on for months as well based on the gap that exists between management and workers. For these reasons, both protests and riots could easily break out in October. I am giving "easily break out" a 94% probability of happening. In addition, there are real tensions between the political opposition parties such as the Frelimo, MDM, and Renamo that could also lead to protests or riots.

Seven such incidents so far this year, above average and gaining some momentum ahead of October - the month that represents to seasonal peak for such activity. Economy appears relatively stable, if subdued. An impending peace deal between government and opposition forces should create a benign backdrop but could also bring grievances to the surface.

Mozambique is a country with a low number of events in the ACLED database, which is a good thing and an indicator of stability.  There are around 24 million people in the Southeastern African state.  I predict a riot event will take place in October 2017, because riot events are one of the most common type of incidents in Mozambique in the ACLED monthly database and the average of the last 4 months is 1 riot event per month.

Well there have been riots or protests with increasing frequency in the country this year, going from one in the first six months to six in the last three (counting September). And I realize that includes four in July. All that being said, I do think some sort of protest/riot is likely in the country. Looking more generally at the fundamentals, the government is running a huge budge shortfall following the revelation of two billion dollars secret government loans last year so there isn't money around to buy off protesters and disgruntled workers. I think the country is going to continue to experience low level instability for some time to come.
